conversation.content: Do you know who I am? I run the lab at Mercy Medical.
Oh absolutely, I can definitely help you with that! So um, let me pull up your account here... I just need your member ID, it should be like MED followed by eight digits on your card.
MED-77298461. There's a charge. Two hundred dollars. Yesterday.

Okay perfect, so I've got your account up here, member MED-77298461, and uh... yeah I can see the charge you're referring to. It's showing as transaction TXN-9847-VK2 from yesterday at 3:47 PM for exactly two hundred dollars, and it looks like it was processed through... hmm, let me check the merchant code here.
Let me see here... I didn't buy anything. What's it for? This is fraud, right?

So basically what I'm seeing is, er, the merchant code MC-4812 indicates it's a telecommunication equipment purchase? And the vendor name is showing as TechMed Solutions LLC, which... actually let me cross-reference this real quick because sometimes these names can be confusing.
TechMed? No. Never heard of them. Hmm, what if... wait, is that medical supplies?

Oh interesting! So actually, um, when I dig deeper into vendor ID VND-88291-TM, they're listed as a medical equipment supplier, not telecom—that merchant code was miscategorized. They sell like phlebotomy supplies, centrifuges, that kind of... but you're saying you didn't authorize this purchase?
No! Cancel it. Now. Do you know how many procedures I handle daily?

Absolutely, I totally understand your concern! So here's what I can do right away—I'm gonna flag this transaction with dispute code DSP-1122-PRIORITY and, uh, freeze any pending charges from that vendor. The thing is though... since it already posted, we'll need to file a formal dispute, which typically takes like three to five business days to resolve.
Three days? What's the word... liability. Who's liable here? I need answers.

Right, so for HSA fraud cases, er, you're protected under regulation HSA-REG-7734, which means you have zero liability once we verify it's unauthorized. What I'm doing now is... actually, hmm, I can expedite this by marking it as case number CASE-99847-EXP for medical professional priority review.
Okay so that means... how fast? The hospital board reviews expenses monthly.

So with the expedited code, we're looking at, um, twenty-four to forty-eight hours max. And actually what I'll do is—I'm generating a provisional credit authorization PCA-7739-TEMP right now, so basically the two hundred dollars will be credited back while we investigate, and that should show up by... let me check... tomorrow morning by 6 AM Eastern.
Tomorrow? Hmm, what if they charge more? Block the whole card?

Yeah so, er, I could block the entire card with security code SEC-FULL-BLOCK, but then you wouldn't be able to use it for anything until the replacement arrives. Or—and this might work better—I can do a selective merchant block just for vendor VND-88291-TM specifically, which means your card still works everywhere else but they can't charge you again.
Selective block. Yes. Do that one. God, this is such a mess.

Perfect, okay so I'm applying selective block SB-4421-ACTIVE right now and... there we go, it's active immediately. Oh and just so you know, um, I'm also adding a fraud alert flag FAF-HIGH to your account, which basically means we'll text you for any charge over fifty dollars for the next thirty days, just to be extra safe.
Fifty's too low. Make it... what's reasonable... hundred fifty?

Absolutely, I can adjust that! So I'm updating the alert threshold to one hundred fifty dollars under modification code MOD-7754-THRESH, and uh... perfect, that's all set. You'll get confirmation text to your number ending in 8827, and er, is there anything else I can help you with today? I know this was stressful but we've got everything protected now.

scenario: phlebotomist, anxious about an unexpected charge on her HSA card
